title: Spooky Season Collection
description: A spooky-cute collection featuring a pumpkin, eyeball coaster, skull applique, and a delicate spiderweb garland.
tips: Use stitch markers for the amigurumi parts to keep track of rounds.
content: This collection started with just the pumpkin, but I couldn't stop! The eyeball coasters are great for using up scrap yarn.

title: Dino Hoodie
description: Fiery red crochet hood with yellow spikes—perfect for little dragons in training.
tips: The crocodile stitch takes a lot of yarn, so make sure to buy an extra skein!
content: Making this hood was a fun challenge. The spikes are worked separately and attached at the end.

title: Baby Yoda
description: A tiny, powerful companion crocheted with soft green and brown yarn.
tips: Safety eyes can be tricky to place correctly—measure twice, click once.
content: The robe is removable! This was a gift for a Star Wars fan and it was a huge hit.

title: Purple Balloon Dog
description: A playful purple 'balloon' dog that will never pop. Soft, squishy, and fun.
tips: Stuff firmly to keep the shape of the 'balloons'.
content: Such a whimsical piece. It looks just like the real thing but much cuddlier.

title: Cactus Sunset Tapestry
description: Desert vibes in fiber form. A colorful tapestry crochet piece featuring saguaros and sunset hues.
tips: Carry the unused yarn colors inside the stitches for a cleaner back.
Use bobbins for each color to prevent tangling.
Count your stitches carefully—tapestry crochet mistakes are hard to fix!
challenges: Managing multiple yarn colors at once was tricky at first.
Keeping the tension even across color changes took practice.
The cactus shapes required careful attention to the chart.
helpful_tips: Start with a smaller swatch to practice the color changes before committing to the full piece.
A yarn bowl or yarn guide helps keep multiple strands organized.
Blocking really makes the design pop—don't skip it!
narrative: I was inspired by a trip to Arizona last spring. The way the sunset painted the desert landscape in oranges, purples, and soft browns stuck with me, and I knew I had to capture it in yarn.

This was my first large-scale tapestry crochet project, and I learned so much along the way. The technique of carrying unused yarn inside the stitches creates a clean back, but it does make the piece thicker and stiffer than regular crochet.
The most challenging part was the cactus shapes. I had to follow a detailed chart and count stitches carefully to get the proportions right. There were definitely a few rows I had to frog and redo!
Now it hangs in my living room and brings back those warm desert memories every time I see it. The colors are so cozy and inviting.

title: Honeycomb Market Tote
description: Mustard and cream hexagon tote bag—sturdy, stylish, and perfect for market days.
tips: Join the hexagons as you go to save time on sewing later.
content: This bag is surprisingly roomy. I lined it with cotton fabric to prevent stretching.

title: Sky Blue Crop Top
description: Textured blue crop top with wide straps. Simple, breezy, and handmade.
tips: Measure against a favorite tank top for the perfect fit.
content: A summer staple. The textured stitch adds interest without being too heavy.

title: Pastel Star Blanket
description: Rainbow star-shaped baby blanket. Ripples of soft color for the little ones.
tips: Count your stitches every few rounds to ensure the points stay sharp.
content: Made with super soft baby yarn. The star shape drapes beautifully.

title: Kitchen Garden Tapestry
description: Detailed tapestry crochet panel featuring garlic in earthy tones.
tips: Use bobbins for color changes to avoid tangles.
content: This piece hangs in my kitchen now. It adds such a warm, homey feel.

title: Easter Table Runner
